declarations.comments:
`Foldable` represents data structures which can be _folded_.

- `foldr` folds a structure from the right
- `foldl` folds a structure from the left
- `foldMap` folds a structure by accumulating values in a `Monoid`

Default implementations are provided by the following functions:

- `foldrDefault`
- `foldlDefault`
- `foldMapDefaultR`
- `foldMapDefaultL`

Note: some combinations of the default implementations are unsafe to
use together - causing a non-terminating mutually recursive cycle.
These combinations are documented per function.
declarations.title: Foldable

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldr` using `foldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldMapDefaultR`.
declarations.title: foldrDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldl` using `foldMap`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldMapDefaultL`.
declarations.title: foldlDefault

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldl`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldlDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapDefaultL

declarations.comments:
A default implementation of `foldMap` using `foldr`.

Note: when defining a `Foldable` instance, this function is unsafe to use
in combination with `foldrDefault`.
declarations.title: foldMapDefaultR

declarations.comments: Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`.
declarations.title: fold

declarations.comments:
Similar to 'foldl', but the result is encapsulated in a monad.

Note: this function is not generally stack-safe, e.g., for monads which
build up thunks a la `Eff`.
declarations.title: foldM

declarations.comments:
Traverse a data structure, performing some effects encoded by an
`Applicative` functor at each value, ignoring the final result.

For example:

```purescript
traverse_ print [1, 2, 3]
```
declarations.title: traverse_

declarations.comments:
A version of `traverse_` with its arguments flipped.

This can be useful when running an action written using do notation
for every element in a data structure:

For example:

```purescript
for_ [1, 2, 3] \n -> do
  print n
  trace "squared is"
  print (n * n)
```
declarations.title: for_

declarations.comments:
Perform all of the effects in some data structure in the order
given by the `Foldable` instance, ignoring the final result.

For example:

```purescript
sequence_ [ trace "Hello, ", trace " world!" ]
```
declarations.title: sequence_

declarations.comments: Combines a collection of elements using the `Alt` operation.
declarations.title: oneOf

declarations.comments: Folds a structure into some `Plus`.
declarations.title: oneOfMap

declarations.comments:
Fold a data structure, accumulating values in some `Monoid`,
combining adjacent elements using the specified separator.

For example:

```purescript
> intercalate ", " ["Lorem", "ipsum", "dolor"]
= "Lorem, ipsum, dolor"

> intercalate "*" ["a", "b", "c"]
= "a*b*c"

> intercalate [1] [[2, 3], [4, 5], [6, 7]]
= [2, 3, 1, 4, 5, 1, 6, 7]
```
declarations.title: intercalate

declarations.comments:
`foldMap` but with each element surrounded by some fixed value.

For example:

```purescript
> surroundMap "*" show []
= "*"

> surroundMap "*" show [1]
= "*1*"

> surroundMap "*" show [1, 2]
= "*1*2*"

> surroundMap "*" show [1, 2, 3]
= "*1*2*3*"
```
declarations.title: surroundMap

declarations.comments:
`fold` but with each element surrounded by some fixed value.

For example:

```purescript
> surround "*" []
= "*"

> surround "*" ["1"]
= "*1*"

> surround "*" ["1", "2"]
= "*1*2*"

> surround "*" ["1", "2", "3"]
= "*1*2*3*"
```
declarations.title: surround

declarations.comments:
The conjunction of all the values in a data structure. When specialized
to `Boolean`, this function will test whether all of the values in a data
structure are `true`.
declarations.title: and

declarations.comments:
The disjunction of all the values in a data structure. When specialized
to `Boolean`, this function will test whether any of the values in a data
structure is `true`.
declarations.title: or

declarations.comments:
`all f` is the same as `and <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the conjunction of the results.
declarations.title: all

declarations.comments:
`any f` is the same as `or <<< map f`; map a function over the structure,
and then get the disjunction of the results.
declarations.title: any

declarations.comments: Find the sum of the numeric values in a data structure.
declarations.title: sum

declarations.comments: Find the product of the numeric values in a data structure.
declarations.title: product

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: elem

declarations.comments: Test whether a value is not an element of a data structure.
declarations.title: notElem

declarations.comments: Try to get nth element from the left in a data structure
declarations.title: indexl

declarations.comments: Try to get nth element from the right in a data structure
declarations.title: indexr

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate.
declarations.title: find

declarations.comments: Try to find an element in a data structure which satisfies a predicate mapping.
declarations.title: findMap

declarations.comments: Find the largest element of a structure, according to its `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: maximum

declarations.comments:
Find the largest element of a structure, according to a given comparison
function. The comparison function should represent a total ordering (see
the `Ord` type class laws); if it does not, the behaviour is undefined.
declarations.title: maximumBy

declarations.comments: Find the smallest element of a structure, according to its `Ord` instance.
declarations.title: minimum

declarations.comments:
Find the smallest element of a structure, according to a given comparison
function. The comparison function should represent a total ordering (see
the `Ord` type class laws); if it does not, the behaviour is undefined.
declarations.title: minimumBy

declarations.comments:
Test whether the structure is empty.
Optimized for structures that are similar to cons-lists, because there
is no general way to do better.
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments:
Returns the size/length of a finite structure.
Optimized for structures that are similar to cons-lists, because there
is no general way to do better.
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments: Lookup a value in a data structure of `Tuple`s, generalizing association lists.
declarations.title: lookup
